text: Islamic civilization developed in a wide geography where different cultures came together for centuries. The most striking aspect of this civilization is its production of knowledge, science, art, and thought that left permanent traces not only in its own inner world but also in world history. The resulting accumulation carries a universal quality as it was shaped by the common effort of scientists belonging to different religions and nations.
Islamic civilization put forward pioneering works in many fields of science, especially between the 8th and 13th centuries. These contributions influenced both the East and the West in later periods.
-Important studies were carried out for algebra to become a systematic science.
-The concept of "Algorithm" passed into world literature from this period.
-Trigonometry tables and calculations were developed, contributing to the progress of astronomy.
-Observatories were established, and detailed studies were conducted on the movements of celestial bodies.
-Calendar calculations were developed; more accurate models regarding sun and moon movements were created.
-Detailed books were written on anatomy, pharmacology, and health services.
-Hospitals became institutions organized at an advanced level according to the conditions of the period.
-Surgical techniques and treatment methods continued to be used in subsequent centuries.
-World maps were shaped more accurately.
-Regional observations made by travelers made a great contribution to geography literature.
Important institutions were established for the preservation and dissemination of knowledge in Islamic civilization.
-Works of the ancient world were translated and developed in centers like the House of Wisdom (Bayt al-Hikmah) in Baghdad.
-The madrasa system made educational activities regular.
-Libraries were used as places where scientists and students could work freely.
Thanks to these institutions, knowledge production continued uninterrupted for many years.
Islamic architecture draws attention with its multicultural structure spreading to wide geographies.
-Mosques, madrasas, bridges, and palaces are not only religious structures; but also aesthetic and engineering achievements.
-Geometric patterns, calligraphy, and ornamentation works reveal the artistic understanding of the period.
-The architectural style extending from Andalusia to Central Asia is still an important part of world heritage today.
Thought life in Islamic civilization showed great diversity.
-Studies on philosophical works reinterpreted ancient thought.
-Comprehensive works were written in the fields of grammar, poetry, and literature.
-Texts written on ethics, politics, and society influenced the thought world of different geographies.
This diversity strongly reflects the multicultural structure of the civilization.
Islamic civilization put forward important developments affecting the social structure, not just scientific and cultural ones.
-Aid institutions, foundations, and social service structures were used to meet the needs of the society.
-Urbanization, waterways, market order, and commercial rules contributed to cities being safe and orderly structures.
-Legal regulations prepared the ground for societies to live within a balance of rights and responsibilities.

content.section: 6. Contribution to the Global Circulation of Knowledge
text: Islamic civilization served as a decisive bridge in the flow of information between East and West.
-The preservation and development of ancient works became one of the preparatory elements of the scientific revival in Europe.
-Many scientific studies were transferred to Europe through Andalusia and translation movements.
-A significant part of the knowledge accumulation extending from the Middle Ages to the modern age could be preserved thanks to this cultural transition.
The contributions of Islamic civilization are directed towards:
-Not just one period,
-Not just one geography,
-Not just one culture,
but the common development of humanity.

Works put forward in science, art, architecture, urbanization, and thought life have been adopted and developed by different societies. Therefore, the production of Islamic civilization is evaluated as a universal heritage.
